newsitem.title: FRANCE: French union leader says trucker hours key issue.
newsitem.headline: French union leader says trucker hours key issue.

text.p: A senior trade union leader said on Wednesday that a 10-day-old truckers' strike choking French roads could only be settled if bosses agreed to pay drivers for loading time and compulsory rest periods on the road.

"It is essential that the employers agree immediately to discuss seriously payment for all hours worked," Force Ouvriere general secretary Marc Blondel said in a statement. "The solution to the conflict lies in a positive response on this inescapable issue."

Striking truckers earlier reported progress in marathon negotiations on another key issue, saying there had been "significant progress" toward a deal on retirement at 55 instead of 60, and that all-night negotiations were continuing non-stop.
They said the consensus on earlier retirement would permit the talks to move on to the truckers' remaining demands for shorter hours and a 10 percent pay rise.
But they said they would not consider any single issue settled until agreement was reached on all points.

In the meantime, union officials vowed to step up their blockade. The truckers have mounted nearly 200 barricades on roads and around refineries and petrol depots across France in a protest that has started to cut deeply into economic activity.
